text: hi my name is Ryan Gosling and I'm the
director of Lost River this scene is at
the beginning of the film it's where we
meet our hero his bones playing by in
the cast occur and he's stripping copper
in these abandoned buildings the movie
began where there was a year where I
would go to Detroit on and off with my
red camera and shoot some of these
buildings hoping to sort of shoot them
before they were torn down this is a
shot that I shot on my own with my red
camera I went away and wrote the
screenplay and then a year later we went
back and shot this close-up of the lead
characters sort of coming out of the
stage and taking the copper piping out
of out of it
Lost River is sort of a dark fairy tale
about one of the last families in a
dying town trying to hold on to their
home and the Lost River is generally
abandoned there are a few sort of people
still still living in it and you know
what one of one of which is this family
was Christina Hendricks and play playing
a character named Billie and her two
sons bones and Frankie part of the
experiment of the movie was to try and
blend the fantasy and the reality of of
this place of Lost River to sort of
bring in people from the neighborhood
and that are really living in these
surreal environments and and bring them
into the fantasy of the film and so that
was a scrapyard where those are guys
that really work there and they really
just that they they're the ones that
sort of you buy that that pay for the
copper so generally we tried not to
affect any of the environments that we
were in you know we made sort of
aesthetic choices to highlight what was
beautiful about them
shot most of the film on 35-millimeter
we shot with these t1 lenses that are
really fast that you can shoot natural
light we generally didn't have any
lights and my cinematographer Ben wanted
to be is like you know really like a
painter with film so he took a real
painterly approach to these natural
environments
